title: The Future of Hacking is Context

rawLines.text: All
right, I want to do something crazy
here. Specifically, I want to talk about
the future of hacking. And what do I
mean by that? What do I mean by hacking?
I mean all hacking, attack defense, bug
bounty, personal automation stacks,
enterprise automation stacks, attacker
automation stacks, enterprise security,
everything, everything hacking related,
I think, is going to come down to what
I'm about to talk about. And I am aware
of how big of a claim that is. The
reason I'm able to make this prediction
is I'm not stupid enough to claim to
know how it's going to happen or exactly
when or with what companies or like what
technologies exactly it's going to
manifest as. That would be ridiculous
because the stuff is basically
unpredictable. What I'm going to show
you is a direction. And I think once you
see it, you will be unable to unsee it.
And by the way, this video is going to
be around 30 minutes, but the whole
first 25 minutes is leading up to the
last five. The last five is the good
stuff. All right. So, quick intro for
people who don't know me. I've been in
security since like 1999 and I went
heavy into AI in late 2022. Still doing
tons of security stuff just with this AI
wrapper around it and you're going to
see why here in a second. And uh I would
say most of my technical background I
mean I've done lots of different stuff
but it kind of boils down to a container
of security assessment. That's like the
main
outline. So first going to show you how
I kind of walked into this idea. So when
I start to do a security assessment,
this goes back, you know, 15, 20 years,
uh, doing security assessments, I like
to start at the very top. When I talk to
a company, I like to interview the CEO,
uh, if if I'm able to, if it's a, you
know, medium-sized company or below. And
I talk to COO, I talk to the CEO, I talk

asking kind of similar questions, but
I'm also asking different questions
because now I'm playing off the answers
I got before. And I just move through
the whole structure all the way down to
the people who who do the actual work.
And then as I keep gathering more and
more information, I start filling in
these elaborate diagrams that describe
to me exactly how this company works.
Like here's how the information flows.
Here's where the data is stored. Oh, we
got vendors over here. They're able to
touch this data or whatever. And
ultimately, I'm trying to figure out
like what they're protecting, how
they're doing it, what day-to-day

technical assessment to find
vulnerabilities. So, I'm also reviewing

but I'm really doing my own as well to
go and probe in these various different
areas and point my uh observations at
things that I've seen in the interviews.
But the underlying theme here is I'm
taking all the context not just of the
vulnerabilities and the technical

kind of how I view and how I start
security assessments. A lot of teams are

with everything evolving, compliance
frameworks, third party risk, customer

back. Slow audits, mis risks, and give

It automates the core parts of your GRC

readiness, vendor risk, and internal

So, in March of 23, I wrote this post

Slack conversations in there, um what

then I can ask questions the same way

So turn that to a couple minutes, right?
The other cool thing is you can respond

This is a real AI system, right? And

Right? So that's threshold. I'm

It's basically a whole bunch of

Turn that into a picture of like where

And I feel like I was doing pretty well

if we look at cyber security in general,
we look at some use cases. there are
some interesting patterns and

do the
task. So, I'm going to take

Oh, it's different this week than it was

for all of
